revision.comment: fixed grammar; clarified language; corrected info on exhibition; updated & edited interpretive overview to include published, academic sources; included quote about this work by the artist
revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:You Are Not Yourself.jpg|thumb|right|''You Are Not Yourself'' (1981)]] '''''You Are Not Yourself''''' is a work of [[appropriation art]] by [[Barbara Kruger]]. Created in 1981,<ref>"[http://arttattler.com/archivepicturesgeneration.html The Range of Disciplines and Artists Known as The Pictures Generation]" Archivepicturesgeneration. Metropolitan Museum of Art, n.d. Accessed April 28, 2015.</ref> ''You Are Not Yourself'' depicts a woman examining herself in a mirror that has presumably been struck and shattered by a bullet.<ref name="Rosenbaum">Rosenbaum, Ron. [http://www.smithsonianmag.com/arts-culture/barbara-krugers-artwork-speaks-truth-to-power-137717540/?no-ist "Barbara Kruger's Artwork Speaks Truth to Power"]. ''Smithsonian Magazine''. N.p., July 2012. Accessed April 28, 2015.</ref> The text "You are not yourself" appears on the photograph, surrounding the image of the woman. The work was included in the exhibition "Barbara Kruger: Belief + Doubt" at the [[Hirshhorn Museum]] in Washington, D.C., which has been on view since 2012.<ref name="Rosenbaum"/><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://hirshhorn.si.edu/explore/barbara-kruger-beliefdoubt/|title=Barbara Kruger: Belief+Doubt - Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden {{!}} Smithsonian|work=Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden {{!}} Smithsonian|access-date=2018-04-15|language=en-US}}</ref>
As is the case with much of Kruger's art, ''You Are Not Yourself'' is often interpreted with a [[feminist]] analysis. Critics have discussed the gendered implications of the image, noting that the woman's shattered reflection suggests the existence of women in society is inherently fragmented. Women are held to many standards and forced to adopt conflicting roles only to become an amalgamation of other's expectations and assumptions; when a woman finally has a moment for self-reflection (or, as Kruger suggests, a chance to catch a glance in the mirror) she finds that she is "not herself".<ref name="rain">Rain&Cupcakes. "[https://whatwhywoman.wordpress.com/2012/12/11/barbara-krugers-you-are-not-yourself/ Barbara Kruger's You Are Not Yourself]." WhatWhyWoman. N.p., December 10, 2012. Accessed April 28, 2015.</ref> The text itself resembles crudely cut and pasted letters that create a jarring tone and echo the theme of breaking. Some critics interpret the image as a call for viewers to consider their own subjectivity and evaluate the societal messages that they may be receiving.<ref name="rain"/> In 1991 interview, Kruger said: "I would venture to guess that many people heed their mirrors at least five times a day and that vigilance certainly can structure physical and psychic identity."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mitchell|first=W.J.T.|date=Winter 1991|title=An Interview with Barbara Kruger|url=https://monoskop.org/File:Mitchell_WJT_1991_An_Interview_with_Barbara_Kruger|journal=Critical Inquiry|volume=17|pages=434-448|via=}}</ref>
The use of pronouns in Kruger's work is often discussed as a potential source of meaning. In ''You Are Not Yourself'', questions have been raised about the identity of the subject that Kruger hails: who is the "you" in question? ''You Are Not Yourself'' features a shattered mirror that has been interpreted to symbolize the reflection of each unique viewer, suggesting that the embedded message is directed towards everyone who views the piece.<ref>Trepsa, Katrina. [http://moodsandappetites.com/you-are-not-yourself/ "You Are Not Yourself"]. ''Moods & Appetites''. N.p., n.d. Web. 06 May 2015.</ref> This image, like others in Kruger's oeuvre, has been used to discuss aspects of [[Outline of critical theory|critical theory]] concerning perception and the nature of self.
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
[[Category:1981 works]] [[Category:American art]] [[Category:Feminist art]]
